column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Drive an Abbot SPG ( Tank )
#Text=The British-designed FV433 " Abbot " was designed for long-ranged bombardment , technically making it a Self-Propelled Gun rather than a tank .
#Text=Now that it 's no longer in military use , most people who see it wo n't have any terminology complaints about this massive vehicle .
#Text=Several Abbots are available to drive at tank-driving entertainment services , if you 're lucky enough to find one near you .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Starting
#Text=the FV433
#Text=Abbot
#Text=Drive only under supervision .
#Text=If you are not trained to drive a tank or self-propelled gun , have an experienced driver ride with you .
#Text=Drive only in open areas with no bystanders .
#Text=There is a standard procedure for checking equipment before starting any tank or SPG .
#Text=Let someone qualified check the panel lights and gauges , and make adjustments to the seat or accelerator pedal to match your size .
#Text=Further adjustments may be necessary in freezing temperatures .
#Text=Enter the driver 's compartment .
#Text=Climb onto the vehicle and lower yourself through the hatch near the front right corner .
#Text=Sit down against the backrest , with your right foot near the gas pedal and your left foot on the footrest .
#Text=Secure the safety harness .
#Text=The compartment to the rear is intended for the three crew members that operate the turret and the machine gun cupola .
#Text=This guide does not cover controlling these weapons .
#Text=Operate the periscope ( optional ) .
#Text=The hatch has a spring-loaded catch that will keep it in open position , which may be the most convenient option for vision .
#Text=If you do need to close the hatch , look through the wide-angle periscope in front of you .
#Text=The periscope has wipers to use in wet weather .
#Text=Put the Abbot in neutral .
#Text=A gearbox with six positions is located on your left .
#Text=You must place the Abbot in neutral before you can start the engine .
#Text=This operates similarly to a normal manual transmission .
#Text=Start the engine .
#Text=Look for the switch labeled " START " on the switchboard in front of you .
#Text=Toggle it to the ON position .
#Text=The rear compartment of the Abbot also has a start switch .
#Text=Either one will start the engine , even if the other is in the off position .
#Text=Select a gear .
#Text=Once the engine is running , move the gearstick to select a gear based on the difficulty of the terrain .
#Text=You can adjust this at any time during the drive , without any other actions required .
#Text=The self-propelled gun will automatically move down in gear if you climb a steep slope .
#Text=Disengage the brakes .
#Text=Hold both steering sticks in front of you .
#Text=Release the brakes by pushing down on the buttons on top of both sticks , until they click .
#Text=The Abbot may begin rolling .
#Text=Do not do this until all bystanders have left the area .
#Text=Move the sticks forward .
#Text=The left stick controls the left tread of the Abbot , while the right stick controls the right tread .
#Text=Keep them in parallel and push them forward if you wish to move forward without turning .
#Text=Driving the FV433 Abbot
#Text=Press the gas pedal .
#Text=Push down gradually with your right foot , exactly as you would in a car .
#Text=This may feel surprisingly smooth and quiet , but be aware that you have much less control over acceleration than you are used to .
#Text=Brake by pulling back on the sticks .
#Text=Pull back both sticks in parallel and release your foot from the pedal .
#Text=This will lock both treads , causing the tank to gradually come to a stop .
#Text=Try this on open ground to get a sense for your stopping distance .
#Text=Turn by pulling back on one stick .
#Text=Turning is as simple as pulling one stick back , locking that tread while the other tread continues to move .
#Text=Pulling back on the left stick will turn the Abbot left , and pulling back on the right stick will turn it right .
#Text=Return both sticks to parallel forward positions when you are done turning .
#Text=Again , practice on open ground before you move into areas with obstacles .
#Text=This has a much larger turn radius than a smaller vehicle .
#Text=Know the numbers .
#Text=Do not let the smooth suspension and easy controls fool you .
#Text=Your instincts as a car or truck driver will not be enough to accurately judge safety .
#Text=These numbers may help you evaluate the situation :
#Text=Your maximum speed is about 50 kilometers per hour ( 30 miles per hour ) .
#Text=The steepest slope you can climb is 30ยบ .
#Text=The vehicle 's width is 2.64 meters ( 8 ft 8 inches ) , mostly on the driver 's left .
#Text=The height is 2.49 meters ( 8 ft 2 inches ) .
#Text=Use caution around water .
#Text=The Abbot is only amphibious after a flotation screen has been attached .
#Text=Do not attempt to enter a deep body of water without training .
#Text=The Abbot is rated to cross ditches and streams up to 2 meters ( 6 ft 9 inches ) across , and up to 1.2 meters ( 4 ft ) across .
#Text=However , entering one too rapidly will splash the driver through the open hatch , or through drainage holes in the floor .
#Text=Engage the brakes and turn off the engine .
#Text=When you are done driving , pull the sticks back and press in the buttons .
#Text=The sticks should remain in the central position .
#Text=Turn off the engine switch and confirm the Abbot has stopped moving before you get out .
#Text=Tips
#Text=If the Abbot will not start , let a trained operator examine it .
#Text=The Indian armed forces manufactured a cheaper version of the gun .
#Text=This uses the same controls , but the lack of rubber on the treads may lead to a bumpier ride .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Needless to say , driving a sixteen ton artillery piece is dangerous .
#Text=Always have a qualified instructor with you .
